title: AB 80
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature acknowledges the My Brother’s Keeper initiative launched by the President to address opportunity gaps for boys and young men of color. The Task Force aims to improve life outcomes for these groups and create equal opportunities for all youth to achieve the American dream. The My Brother’s Keeper Task Force recognizes the diversity among boys and men of color, with various factors influencing their experiences. The initiative focuses on milestones such as early education, high school graduation, postsecondary education, workforce entry, and providing second chances. The My Brother’s Keeper Task Force Report highlights disparities faced by boys and men of color in areas such as poverty, fatherless households, high school dropout rates, unemployment, homicide, and imprisonment. Recommendations from the report influence California policy, enhancing the state's competitiveness for federal funding and economic strength. The Assembly Select Committee on the Status of Boys and Men of Color in California recognizes the importance of supporting young people of color, especially boys and young men, to ensure California's future prosperity and health. By 2050, boys and men of color are projected to make up close to 80 percent of the state's male population. This demographic shift poses a serious threat to California's economic strength and competitiveness. The Assembly Select Committee on the Status of Boys and Men of Color in California focuses on key issues like health, education, juvenile justice, employment, and youth development. Community leaders partner with government to improve outcomes for young people of color. An Interagency Task Force on the Status of Boys and Men of Color is established in the Government Code. The Interagency Task Force on the Status of Boys and Men of Color in state government aims to support leaders in addressing challenges faced by this population and improving their life outcomes. It includes key department, agency, and systems leaders and is guided by the Final Report and Policy Platform for State Action. The task force consists of 20 members. The Interagency Task Force on the Status of Boys and Men of Color in state government comprises 20 members, including key leaders from various departments and agencies. Members include representatives from the Senate and Assembly, Superintendent of Public Instruction, Presidents of the University of California and California State University, Chancellor of the California Community Colleges, and other designated officials from relevant departments. The Interagency Task Force on the Status of Boys and Men of Color in state government includes key leaders from various departments and agencies, such as the Secretary of Business, Consumer Services, Secretary of Labor, Director of Employment Development, and others. The Interagency Task Force on the Status of Boys and Men of Color in state government, chaired by the Chief Justice of California or designee, consists of members with desirable qualifications. Meetings are subject to the Bagley-Keene Open Meetings Act. The Interagency Task Force on the Status of Boys and Men of Color in state government, chaired by the Chief Justice of California or designee, has the powers and authority to employ personnel, hold hearings, make agreements, cooperate with other state agencies, and appoint advisers when needed for projects. The Interagency Task Force on the Status of Boys and Men of Color in state government, chaired by the Chief Justice of California or designee, has the powers and authority to accept federal funds, gifts, donations, grants, or bequests for its purposes. Within six months, the task force must assess existing programs aligning with federal priorities and the Governor's Budget to identify areas of alignment. The Interagency Task Force on the Status of Boys and Men of Color in California, chaired by the Chief Justice or designee, has the authority to accept funds and assess existing programs for alignment with state goals. The task force's long-term responsibilities include reviewing the action plan of the Assembly Select Committee on the Status of Boys and Men of Color, identifying state goals and barriers, assessing policies and programs, and preparing data on boys and men of color in California. The Interagency Task Force on the Status of Boys and Men of Color in California, chaired by the Chief Justice or designee, will serve as a liaison to departments and agencies, ensuring engagement and partnership with public, nonprofit, and philanthropic entities. The task force will convene quarterly to assess progress on its responsibilities and strengthen partnerships with external leaders. The first meeting will be held by January 31, 2016. The task force will prepare and submit an annual report to the Legislature on department and agency findings. They will also report these findings at the Assembly Select Committee on the Status of Boys and Men of Color in California's annual hearing. The task force's duties are advisory only, and there is no obligation to implement their findings without further legislation. The Boys and Men of Color Task Force Fund is created in the State Treasury to support the task force with funds from gifts or donations. The chapter will be in effect until January 1, 2026, and then repealed.
